Name: 77 Days in September: A Novel of Survival, Dedication, and Love (The Kyle Tait Series) (Volume 1)

ReviewList.Text: This book was recommended to me.  I was somewhat skeptical as I began reading, but was quickly drawn in.  It has all the elements of an excellent novel.  The characters are well defined, believable and easy to relate to.  The plot, however fictitious, is grounded in reality and calls attention to a truly catastrophic, yet largely ignored threat to international security.  The plot and pacing are first rate, as the story never dragged or failed to hold my interest.  More importantly, it made me *care* about the people and events as I read.  Ray Gorham has done an outstanding job in researching and writing this novel.

I think we have talent here.  From the Forward I was hooked. The idea of an EMP never crossed my mind and it made the story line believable.  What better way to hold your interest than to have two people deeply attached to each other trying desperately to get back together after a major event changes all the circumstances of their separation.  All the subplots fit tightly especially Doug. The experiences that Kyle had as he tried to get back to Montana were very real.  There were no slow spots in the storyline.  A very good summer read.

Author.Name: T. Young, Author of How to Make Money Homesteading

ReviewList.Text: I'm dipping my toes into the waters of reviewing on Amazon, largely because of the courteous plea to do so by the author in a note at the end of the book. I have been on a post-apocalyptic reading jag for a while now, and this novel is in the middle of the pack for me. It moves right along, contains only a few errors (wretch when author means retch, as in to dry heave, strait when the author means straight, as in straight hair.) Having read more than a few novels which clearly hadn't been edited, read aloud by the author, or even run through a spell-checker, I appreciate what I used to take for granted in a novel - that I wouldn't be bumped out of it constantly by blatant errors in spelling, punctuation, formatting, etc. There are several pretty decent plain language explanations of how an EMP creates the destruction that it does, which are helpful to anybody who doesn't understand it to begin with. SPOILER ALERT:I will say that I was never in any real doubt that Kyle would make it home. It would have been a nice twist if he had frozen to death and Rose had found his journal and some months or years later it had gotten to Jenn. Not nice in the sense that it would have been a nice outcome for the character, but nice in the sense that the reader's expectations have been upended, and now they really need to pay attention because they don't know what's coming next. But a tidy little novel, a happy ending, nice motivation to prepare for the unexpected if you haven't yet begun to do so. For me, the best post-EMP novel remains One Second After. But this novel is worth the $3.99 Kindle price if you enjoy these types of stories. I would encourage the author to make his next novel more complex, and include more of the challenges any community would face after an EMP event. He alluded to the better prepared people in Deer Creek not participating in the council, leaving people in need with not much to give to try to figure things out. This really could have been a source for a lot of juicy conflict. Does the council send emissaries to ask these better-prepared people for help? What kind of reception do they receive? What is the response, the rationale for either helping or not? I'm giving this novel three stars; I'd give One Second After four stars, and save five stars for Cormac McCarthy's The Road.
This is a great idea looking for a good writer. This book isn't it.  Reading it on a Kindle made me long for an EMP to wipe out technology.

Author.Name: Just looking for a good story...

ReviewList.Text: Excellent read. I sat down to read a couple of chapters and ended up sitting up all night and part of the next day, reading non-stop. The characters and their storylines were compelling; you wanted to find out what  was going to happen. Definitely a scarey idea if a EMP event were to take place in space over the continental US and the resulting damage to North American electrical and computer systems.

my favorite past time is reading. I was recommended this book from a friend, so I read the description and gave it try. I was skeptical at first because most books I read are Thrillers or love stories. I could not put this book down. I loved the Character and just felt myself following him in his Journey. The Author did a great job on this book and I will add him to my list of authors to watch out for more books.
